repnme.cdata!:
Mauritania - Integrated Development Project
            for Irrigated Agriculture

abstracts.cdata!:
The Integrated Development Project for
            Irrigated Agriculture had a satisfactory outcome, likely
            sustainability, substantial institutional development
            impact, and satisfactory performances by both Bank and
            Borrower.  External factors affecting the project included
            the floods of 1999, periodic drought, the drop in world
            purchases of rice, and the uncontrolled import of Senegalese
            rice all along the Valley.  Among the lessons learned were:
            The APL's key features of long-term commitment and
            flexibility in execution facilitated the initiation and
            maintenance of liberalization policies for the Government of
            Mauritania; Sustainability of rehabilitated schemes depend
            on the quality of work and sufficient amount of funding
            provided for operation and maintenance; Land registration
            needs to focus more on cooperative farmers; Flood control
            infrastructure needs to be supported by public funds; Civil
            works enterprises based outside Mauritania should be
            encouraged to effectively participate and partner with
            Mauritanians; Capacity building of public and private
            providers is necessary; Agricultural diversification in
            Mauritania is a viable growth and employment strategy and
            should be strongly promoted; A participatory approach that
            empowers producers and their organizations in the design and
            implementation of development operations is needed for
            sustainability; An effective communication strategy is
            needed to ensure coordination and dissemination; and an
            efficient monitoring and evaluation system should be
            designed early in the project's life.

repnme.cdata!:
Mauritania - Integrated Development Project
            for Irrigated Agriculture

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Integrated
            Development Project for Irrigated Agriculture (first phase)
            in Mauritania, is to lay the foundation for a sustainable
            development of irrigated agriculture in technical,
            financial, environmental, and socioeconomic terms. The
            project conforms to the Country Assistance Strategy (CAS)
            objectives, in support of the government's long-term
            strategy for the rehabilitation, and sustainable development
            of irrigated agriculture, and, in the construction of basic
            rural infrastructures in the Senegal River Valley. To
            accomplish these objectives, the main components will: 1)
            create the policy, legal, and, institutional frameworks to
            ease the development of irrigated agriculture; 2) develop
            basic public and private infrastructures. Research and
            development will be supported under this component; 3)
            improve management and organizational skills within farmers,
            as well as farmer associations; 4) strengthen the
            traditional irrigated agriculture sub-sector, supporting
            traditional crop production; 5) develop agricultural
            diversification, through promotion activities, focusing on
            quality control. Infrastructure development will also be
            supported; 6) implement mitigation measures, in response to
            adverse environmental impacts caused by the project; 7)
            provide management, and, monitoring and evaluation for
            project related issues.

repnme.cdata!:
Mauritania - Integrated Development Project
            for Irrigated Agriculture (PDIAIM) : environmental impact assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
This is an environmental impact
            assessment for the Integrated Development Project for
            Irrigated Agriculture for Mauritania, which aims to promote
            the sustainable increase of agricultural productivity and
            income in a rural environment, improve food security, and
            reduce poverty--all within the context of integrating the
            management of natural resources. To offset reduced water
            availability, water use will be monitored and divided up
            among users. Water drainage networks and environmental
            monitoring will restore soil salinity and check soil
            erosion. The water table will be maintained. Deforestation,
            ecological imbalances, biodiversity alterations, and the
            spread of water-borne diseases like bilharzia, will be
            mitigated by restricting irrigation to certain lands.
            Socio-economic impacts like the marginalization of certain
            groups will be addressed by providing supports for
            populations-at-risk. Building community infrastructure will
            reduce loss of social cohesion and the risk of social conflicts.

docna.cdata!:
Mauritania - Integrated Development Project
            for Irrigated Agriculture (PDIAIM) : environmental impact assessment

display_title.display_title:
Mauritanie – Projet de
            développement intégré de l’agriculture irriguée (PDIAIM) :
            évaluation d’impact environnemental (Vol. 4)
